title: How many games can you intentionally ruin before being banned?
body:
Serious question. I saw that one Nunu guy with 60 games trolled in a row and no ban. Only reason he got banned was because somebody @RiotSupport and then even with 47 losses and building zeal items and going 0/10 in nearly 47 games they still tried to give him the benefit of the doubt. What's the line on the amount of games you're allowed to intentionally ruin without being banned?

[Picture Removed by Moderation]

> [{quoted}](name=C9 Scott,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=eH9Ekka9,comment-id=000000000006,timestamp=2019-09-16T12:59:33.884+0000)

My expectations? That trolls get punished when they've shown a consistent history to negatively affect games, backed by reports that indicate what was negative. And that such reports do not affect players who are honestly trying to win a game. 

A problem that many folks have with the current system is that it's not quick enough, which makes sense since it can be difficult to discern trolling and trying to win. Added to the fact that sometimes it's blatant and some folks seem to go unpunished. But what you don't see very often? People complaining that they were actively trying to win and still got punished, then upon review had a removal. I very seldom see those threads. So on the latter part, people not getting punished when they were not doing things wrong, I'm happy about.

Like most others, I think there could be improvements in people inting and trolling.

Honestly, I don't know their criteria. But, I'd think they should have parameters set in place that can tell *obvious* feeding versus any other behavior. But I don't know how they detect intentional feeding, and it's probably for the better, since that public knowledge could be used to avoid detection.

If it's caught at any instance, it's given a ban.

A note about people saying they're doing something, like feeding/trolling: that's clearly negative behavior, but that doesn't mean they're actually doing the negative actions they describe. So, chat doesn't automatically make identifying this easier. More descriptive reports probably do.
